title: Lion cub tries to sound vicious... but only manages a high-pitched squeak
text:
A lion cub tried to let out a mighty roar... but the tiny creature could only manage a high-pitched squeak.

The baby lion, who was part of an education programme at a zoo, was separated from its mother so handlers could monitor its growth.

It is not clear where the video, taken in 2010, was filmed.

Footage, taken at a zoo, shows a lion cub trying to let out a mighty roar but the tiny creature can only manage a high-pitched squeak

In the clip, the adorable cub lies on a white blanket as an onlooker says 'kitty' multiple times.

The animal lifts its cheeks baring its teeth while letting out a tiny, high-pitched squeak.

Onlookers can be heard saying 'aw' at the adorable noise.

Someone asks if the animals all make that sound and a zoo worker replies: 'It will turn into a growl later.'

When the animal makes the noise again the zoo worker adds: 'Aah you're so vicious, come on!'

As the animal begins to move, one person says: 'Get up little baby.'

In the clip, the animal lifts its cheeks baring teeth while letting out a squeak. It is not clear where the video, taken in 2010, was filmed

It continues to squeak as onlookers laugh and one says: 'Aw, it's okay.'

As the animal lies back down, a male voice can be heard saying: 'That is one good-looking cat!'

Rachel Kane posted the footage to YouTube with the caption: 'I uploaded this video a few months ago. It was taken in December 2010 on a 'behind-the-scenes' tour at a zoo.

'His sister had died shortly after their birth. He was a part of the third pair of cubs born to the pride that year.

Someone asks if the animals all make that sound and a zoo worker replies: 'It will turn into a growl later'

'The cubs are routinely separated from their mother after birth in order to get them acclimated to their handlers and also to keep better eye on their growth and development.

'The cubs were a part of an educational program at the facility geared towards school kids. He was eventually reunited with his mother and the rest of the lions.'

When fully grown, a lion can roar up 114 decibels. This is around the same level of noise as a live rock concert.
description: The tiny cub was part of an education programme at a zoo, although it is unclear where the clip was taken. The baby was separated from its mother so handlers could monitor its growth.
